This chapter discussed the process of identifying, locating and correcting problems that occur.

  • Gathering information and verifying that the problem exists are important first steps in the troubleshooting process.

  • When troubleshooting, there are several structured troubleshooting techniques that can be used including: top-down, bottom-up, divide-and-conquer.

  • Less structured techniques include trial and error and substitution.

  • Experienced troubleshooters tend to rely on experience and less structured techniques for troubleshooting issues.

There are several tools available to help in the troubleshooting process.

  • Physical problems are concerned mainly with the hardware of devices as well as cabling connections.

  • Physical issues are often detected using the senses.

  • A number of software utility programs are available that can help identify network problems.

  • Some of the most common software utilities used for troubleshooting include: ipconfig, ping, tracert, nslookup, netstat.

There are several issues to check for when troubleshooting wired and wireless networks.

  • LED lights are used to indicate the current state or activity of a piece of equipment or connection.

  • For wired devices, check physical connectivity and cabling issues including: wrong cable type, bad termination, physical damage, and port placement.

  • For a wireless client, connectivity problem such as: A/B/G/N compatibility, overlapping channels, signal strength, and interference should be examined. Also, check the SSID, authentication and encryption settings.

  • On both wired and wireless clients, check the IP configuration of the client, including IP address, subnet mask, default gateway and DNS information.

  • Verify connectivity between the ISR and the ISP by checking the router status page in the ISR to ensure that an IP address is assigned by the ISP and the connection is good.

There are several sources of help when troubleshooting issues.

  • Documentation such as topology maps, network diagrams and addressing schemes, assists the troubleshooting effort.

  • Outside resources available to help with troubleshooting include: previously kept documentation, online FAQs, colleagues and other network professionals, Internet forums.

  • A helpdesk is a group of individuals with the knowledge and tools required to help diagnose and correct common problems.

  • First, second and third-level helpdesk support is often available with escalation procedures in place to help solve issues.

  • It is important to document all steps taken in the troubleshooting process, including interaction with the helpdesk.

Bottom-up Always starts at the physical layer and works its way up until it finds a faulty layer. More suited for complex cases. It is a slow, but solid approach. When the problem is application (or upper layer) related, this approach can take a long time.

Troubleshooting Approach How it operates Cases for which it is suitable Advantages/
Disadvantages
Divide-and-conquer Based on the circumstances (reported issues) and your experience, you might decide to start at any layer and work up or down the OSI stack. Most suitable when you are experienced and the problem has precise symptoms. It approaches the layer of the culprit faster than the other approaches.
You need experience to use this approach effectively.

**exact meaning of colors may vary according to equipment and manufacturer

• Indicates the current condition of the device and can change color or flash.
  • Used during device self-diagnostic testing to indicate stage of completion.When self-diagnostics are completed.
  • **solid green indicate device is functioning properly
  • **amber can indicate that an error has been encountered that is correctable, such as a missing or damaged operating systems.
  • **red can indicate that the device has experienced a major hardware problem which will require service.
Wireless Activity LED

• sometimes referred to as link lights, an activity LED is normally associated with a specific port
  • Normal condition is to flash indicating that traffic is flowing through the port On some devices the rate of flash indicates the speed that the port is operating.
  • **solid green indicates that a device is plugged into the port but no traffic is flowing.
  • **amber indicates the device is making adjustments to the way the port is operating.
  • **No light indicates that nothing is plugged into the port, or there is an issue with the port, transmitting device or cable
  • On wireless devices: activity light can indicate status of the radio connection; flash rate differs depending on if the clients are associated or searching for an association.
